{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3575377,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T19:55:10.838Z","cooked":"

So I cannot seem to get Choreo to land at the setpoint I chose. I’m constantly modifying PID values. Overshooting then undershooting. Second guessing whether 10, 10, 7 are fake numbers or the actual numbers. Do these numbers scale with velocity. When I use these numbers I get definite translation oscillation. Going really slow 1mps.

I’m pulling my hair out (what little I have left chasing either error correction or setpoints. What am I doing wrong?

Anyhoo. Mild meltdown over. Any help/thoughts would be appreciated.

auto-reorg branch

codebase

There is a massive overshoot at the beginning which settles on. But I can’t make it vanish no matter which no value I use. I don’t know the order of magnitude for these values. Limelight tracking is good. Should I use a smaller motor torque?

Do the stop point constraints need to be set to the last two wayspoints. say 1 and 2 if a simple path. Or will Start/End work?

Start and End are what you should be using. Given that, I would guess the motor torque is too high. You might have put in stall torque, which is not achievable at speed. Try 0.4 N*m as a general starting point.

We’re also having a similar issue where our robot consistently overshoots whenever we place a setpoint in the correct position, e.g. directly against the coral station. We’ve already turned the motor torque down to 0.75 N*m, and that helped a bit, but the robot still overshoots by ~5 inches. Any ideas of why this could be happening?
Our code is here: GitHub - 4639RoboSpartans/2025-Heart-of-the-Sea
